[[Image:Gamar almazade49 3.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Gamar Almaszadeh]] '''Gamar Hajiaga qizi Almaszadeh''' ({{lang-az| Qəmər Hacıağa qızı Almaszadə}}) (10 March 1915, [[Baku]] – 7 April 2006, [[Baku]]) was an [[Azerbaijan]]i ballerina and ballet instructor. She's considered the first ballerina of the [[Muslim world]].<ref>[http://azer.com/aiweb/categories/magazine/ai103_folder/103_articles/103_almaszade.html My Life as Azerbaijan's First Ballerina]</ref>
==Early life== Gamar Almaszadeh (nicknamed Tamara) was born in [[Baku]] to a family of a shoemaker and a midwife, Hajiaga and Maryam Almaszadeh. She became interested in [[ballet]] at a very young age, when she saw her friend perform ballet moves. Persuaded by her friend she signed up for ballet lessons at a private studio (later reorganized into the Baku School of Choreography). Gamar's mother approved of her daughter's new interest but her father Hajiaga Almaszadeh, a conservative [[Muslim]], had to be misled into believing that Gamar was attending gym in order to have him pay for her lessons. The secret was soon revealed and, as expected, Gamar's father did not come around to her choice. However he was reported to have secretly assisted at his daughter's performances later, when she became a renowned ballerina.<ref name="azerbintl">[http://www.azer.com/aiweb/categories/magazine/ai103_folder/103_articles/103_almaszade.html Center Stage: My Life as Azerbaijan's First Ballerina] by Gamar Almaszadeh. ''Azerbaijan International''. #10.3. Autumn 2002</ref>
==Career==
After graduating from the choreographic school in 1930, Gamar Almaszadeh began working at the [[Azerbaijan State Opera and Ballet Theatre]]. To meet her father's expectations, she also enrolled in a teachers' college. In 1932, she left for [[Moscow]] to continue her ballet education but soon returned to Baku after being chosen to perform a secondary role in [[Reinhold Glière]]'s opera ''Shakh-Senem''.<ref name="azerbintl"/> In 1933, she was admitted to a professional ballet school in [[St. Petersburg]], where she had Maria Romanova-Ulanova (mother of the world-famous ballerina [[Galina Ulanova]]) as an instructor.<ref>{{az icon}} [http://www.musigi-dunya.az/Magazine3/articles/30/30.html The Founder of Ballet in Azerbaijan] by K.Shahverdiyev. ''Musigi-dunya.az''. 2000</ref> In 1936, she finished her studies and once again returned to Baku. In 1937, she founded the [[Azerbaijan State Folk Song and Dance Ensemble]] affiliated with the [[Azerbaijan State Philharmonic Society]]. Guided by composer [[Uzeyir Hajibeyov]], she organized research expeditions to various parts of Azerbaijan to film and document folk dance performances and to enrich the repertoire of her ensemble as well as to propagate them on the big scene.<ref name="azerbintl"/> In 1939, she taught her first choreography class and in 1940, made her first biggest performance in the lead role of [[Afrasiyab Badalbeyli]]'s ''Giz Galasi'' ("The Maiden Tower").<ref name="azerbintl"/> She later became head of the School of Choreography (one of her students was prominent Azerbaijani ballerina [[Leyla Vakilova]]). During her career, she toured [[France]], [[India]], and [[Nepal]]. In 1970, she was invited to [[Baghdad]] by [[Iraq]]'s Ministry of Culture to promote Iraqi folk dance culture and founded the Iraq Folk Dance Ensemble.<ref name="azerbintl"/> She retired from ballet in the 1950s, but remained an instructor at the School of Choreography until the late 1990s.
She married Afrasiyab Badalbeyli in 1931, however the marriage did not last very long.<ref name="gubek">{{ru icon}} [http://www.baku.ru/blg-list.php?id=6278&usp_id=73942&cmm_id=0 Azerbaijan's First Ballerina] by Nonna de Gubek. ''Baku Pages''. 1 July 2005</ref>
==Trivia== *Gamar Almaszadeh's younger sister Adila Almaszadeh also took ballet lessons and went off to St. Petersburg to study professional ballet. However the asperity of the northern climate affected Adila's health (as she was extremely sensitive to climate change) leading to her death of [[tuberculosis]].<ref name="gubek"/> *In the 1930s, a religious fanatic attempted to assassinate Gamar Almaszadeh on her way out of the theatre, but the bullet hit the spike heel of her shoe leaving Gamar unharmed.<ref name="gubek"/>
==References== {{commons category|Gamar Almaszadeh}} {{reflist}}

{{Infobox company | name = GEOSET | logo = GEOSETlogo.png | type = Educational Initiative | founder = [[Sir Harold Kroto]] | foundation = 2006 | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Colin Byfleet ''(Co-Founder)''
Steve Acquah ''(Co-Founder & Director)''
David Simpson ''(Co-Founder)''
Penny Gilmer ''(Co-Founder)'' | services = [[E-learning]], [[Education]] | homepage = {{URL|www.geoset.info}} , {{URL|www.geoset.fsu.edu}} }} '''GEOSET''' (Global Educational Outreach for Science Engineering and Technology) is a nonprofit educational initiative founded by the Nobel Laureate [[Sir Harold Kroto]] in 2006 to provide a “free resource of educational material”. Students record presentations detailing their work or interests on a subject matter. The presentations can also form part of course assessment.http://www.mediatheque.lindau-nobel.org/videos/31302/the-revolutionary-impact-of-the-gooyouwiki-world-gyww-on-education-and-student-success-lecture-discussion-2010/laureate-kroto (Time 36:39), http://www.journaloffloridastudies.org/files/JFSms1-1-10_PDF.pdf The main GEOSET website is a database gateway that links all the contributing institutions and the local site and contains presentations produced at the [[Florida State University]] GEOSET Studios. Some of the students who have recorded presentations have been successful in obtaining job offers when showing the video to perspective employers.http://www.tallahasseemagazine.com/January-February-2010/Just-Call-Him-Harry/ ==History== [[File:Harold Kroto 1c389 8471.sweden.jpg|left|thumb|220px|GEOSET founder Sir Harold Kroto.]] The inspiration for GEOSET was based on the ability of [[Google]], [[YouTube]] and [[Wikipedia]] to enable people across the world to access a repository of educational material. Harold Kroto called this revolution the "Goo-You-Wiki World".(http://www.mediatheque.lindau-nobel.org/videos/31302/the-revolutionary-impact-of-the-gooyouwiki-world-gyww-on-education-and-student-success-lecture-discussion-2010/laureate-kroto) Participating organizations and institutions are encouraged to record presentations and create a local site to host them. The [[URL]]s from the presentations and representative images are then added to a GEOSET database site. The videos produced make up a series of concepts which teachers are encouraged to use.(http://archive.tallahassee.com/article/20091001/FSVIEW/90930025/Kroto-talks-science-ed-NPR ) There are many participating institutions including the [[University of Sussex]],(http://www.sussex.ac.uk/geoset) [[Sheffield University]](http://www.geokri.org/) and [[Toyo University]].(http://bionano.toyo.ac.jp/GEOSET-index.html) The initiative has also been demonstrated in the [[Middle East]] with the aim of strengthening the resources for science research (https://www.fsu.edu/news/2005/05/25/petra.conference/)(http://www.ameinfo.com/blog/education-&-childcare/middle-east-science-fund/professor-kroto-visits-just-yarmouk-and-jordan-universities-to-introduce-geoset-initiative-in-jordan/)(http://www.meed.com/sectors/economy/education/professor-kroto-visits-just-yarmouk-and-jordan-universities-to-introduce-geoset-initiative-in-jordan/3011446.article) and in [[China]],(http://www.ebeijing.gov.cn/feature_2/Nobel_Prize_Forum_2007/VIP_Guests_2007/t919198.htm) with Anhui University of Technology (AHUT) being one of the first to join the GEOSET initiative.(http://en.ahut.edu.cn/info/1001/1118.htm) ==Technology== [[File:Geoset recording.png|left|thumb|440px|A dual screen recording of a student giving a presentation.]] Capture station technology provided by Mediasite is used to record presentations at Florida State University (http://www.sonicfoundry.com/impact-award/florida-state-university-geoset) with other [[rich media]] formats such as [[Adobe Presenter]](http://www.legacy.geoset.fsu.edu/swa/quiz1/index.htm) and Camtasia Studios.(http://www.legacy.geoset.fsu.edu/presentations/harry_vignettes_Don_Marquis/harry_vignettes_Don_Marquis.html) However international partner organizations have used a variety of recording options.(http://www.geokri.org/) The Florida State University GEOSET facility opened a centralized recording studio in the Paul Dirac Science Library.(http://www.fsunews.com/article/20130917/FSVIEW/130917012/Dirac-Science-Library-reopens-after-renovations-future-upgrades-planned) The studio is primarily student run with Dr. Steve Acquah and Sir Harold Kroto directing.(http://www.worldofwebcast.com/blog/2014-06)(http://www.asianscientist.com/features/nobel-laureate-sir-harold-kroto-buckyball-discovery-science-education-and-creativity-2012/)(http://www.caracol.com.co/noticias/internacionales/la-iniciativa-geoset-fomenta-ensenanza-y-divulgacion-cientifica-en-a-latina/20140202/nota/2068866.aspx) GEOSET is also expanding into South America with a joint technology collaboration with the [[Universitat Politècnica de València]], demonstrating [[Polimedia]] instructional technology to government representatives and universities including [[Uruguay]], [[Colombia]], [[Costa Rica]] and [[Peru]].(http://www.lasprovincias.es/agencias/20140202/comunitatvalenciana/comunitat/geoset-fomentan-ensenanza-divulgacion-cientifica_201402021207.html) ==Recognition== In May 2008 GEOSET received a finalist award for the [[Sonic Foundry]] Rich Media Impact Awards in the category of Global Reach.(http://www.sonicfoundry.com/press-release/sonic-foundry-names-finalists-fourth-annual-rich-media-impact-awards) In 2009 GEOSET won the Rich Media Impact Award in the category of Global Reach.(http://www.sonicfoundry.com/press-release/sonic-foundry-announces-winners-fifth-annual-rich-media-impact-awards) In 2010, GEOSET received $100,000 from [[Microsoft]] Research for science education.(http://artsandsciences.fsu.edu/In-the-News/Microsoft-gives-100K-to-FSU-for-science-education) In May 2014 GEOSET Studios won the Enterprise Video Award in the category of Educational Scholarship (http://www.sonicfoundry.com/press-release/sonic-foundry-announces-winners-10th-annual-enterprise-video-awards) ==See also== * [[OpenCourseWare]] * [[Crash Course (YouTube)]] * [[Khan Academy]] * [[MIT OpenCourseWare]] ==References== {{Reflist|3}} [[Category:Florida State University]] [[Category:Online education]] [[Category:OpenCourseWare]]

{{Infobox Organization |name = The Horse Rangers Association |image = Horse Rangers Association logo.jpg |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 1954<ref name="Horse and Hound">{{cite news | url=http://www.horseandhound.co.uk/news/397/315394.html | title=Horse Rangers puts out call for former members to get in touch | work=[[Horse and Hound]] | date=19 December 2012 | accessdate=29 March 2013 | author=White, Charlotte | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121221011415/http://www.horseandhound.co.uk/news/397/315394.html | archivedate=21 December 2012 | df= }}</ref> |extinction = |type = |status = charity |purpose = |headquarters = [[London]] |location = [[Hampton Court]], [[London]] |region_served= |membership = |language = English |leader_title = Director|leader_name = Jeremy Richardson<ref name="Proto">{{cite news | url=http://www.richmondandtwickenhamtimes.co.uk/news/11262201.Horse_Rangers_Association_appoints_new_director/?ref=var_0 | title=Horse Rangers Association appoints new director | work=[[Richmond and Twickenham Times]] | date=7 June 2014 | accessdate=7 June 2014 | author=Proto, Laura}}</ref> |main_organ = ''The Horse Rangers Association’s Newsletter'' |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{URL|http://www.horserangers.com/}} |remarks = }}
'''The Horse Rangers Association''' is a registered [[Charitable organization|charity]] which teaches horsemanship and management of [[horses]]<ref name="Horse and Hound"/> so that youngsters of all backgrounds and abilities, from the age of 8 years, can benefit in their own personal development.<ref name="About Us">{{cite web | url=http://www.horserangers.com/html/about_us.html | title=About Us | publisher=Horse Rangers Association | accessdate=29 March 2013}}</ref> It is not a [[riding school]].
The Association is based at The Royal Mews, [[Hampton Court]] in the [[London Borough of Richmond upon Thames]]. A member group of the [[Riding for the Disabled Association]] (RDA), it is registered with the [[British Horse Society]] (BHS).
==History==
The Horse Rangers Association was founded in [[Shepperton]] in 1954 by Raymond Gordon. The charity relocated to the [[Royal Mews#Other locations|Royal Mews, Hampton Court]] during the 1960s. Raymond Gordon’s vision was to enable young people, who would not otherwise have the opportunity, to manage horses and ride; from early in the charity’s existence this included young people with [[special needs]].
==Activities== More than 400 children and young people attend classes at the Association each week.<ref name="Buchanan">{{cite news | url= http://www.richmondandtwickenhamtimes.co.uk/news/10261295.New_route_for_Rangers/ | title=New route for Horse Rangers' Association parade | work=[[Richmond and Twickenham Times]] | date=1 March 2013 | accessdate=29 March 2013 | author=Buchanan, Clare | pages=4}}</ref> The Association's special needs classes operate at its indoor school, located at the Stockyard, [[Bushy Park]].
==Organisation== The [[Board of directors|board of trustees]] is chaired by Richard Bevan.<ref name="Proto"/>
==External links== * [http://www.horserangers.com// Official website] * [http://www.facebook.com/horserangers/ Facebook page] * [https://www.youtube.com/user/HorserangersHRA/ You Tube page] * [Tweet @horserangers] *{{EW charity |1098257}} ==References and footnotes== {{Reflist|1}}

'''Indonesia Corruption Watch''' (ICW) is an Indonesian-based and led [[non-governmental organization]] (NGO) whose primary mission is to monitor and report to the public incidents of corruption in [[Indonesia]]. ICW is also heavily engaged in the prevention and deterrence of corruption through education, cultural change, prosecutions and system reform.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rachman|first1=Anita|title=In Indonesia, Acceptance of Corruption Starts Young|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indonesiarealtime/2014/05/29/in-indonesia-acceptance-of-corruption-starts-young/|accessdate=10 August 2015|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=29 May 2014}}</ref> The organization was formed in [[Jakarta]] on June 21, 1998 to prevent corruption in post-Suharto governments.<ref>{{cite web|title=Indonesia Corruption Watch: Allard Prize Finalist|url=http://www.allardprize.org/indonesia-corruption-watch-allard-prize-finalist|website=Allard Prize for International Integrity|publisher=Peter A. Allard School of Law|accessdate=10 August 2015}}</ref>
ICW's work and influence in Indonesia as a major NGO in its field has been recognized and extensively reported on since 1998 by Indonesian and major international news media. The [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]] considers ICW to be "the leading NGO" focused on fighting corruption in Indonesia.<ref>{{cite web|title=UNODC database Indonesia Corruption Watch (ICW)|url=https://www.unodc.org/ngo/showSingleDetailed.do?req_org_uid=16645|website=UNODC|publisher=United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime}}</ref> The [[World Bank]] cites multiple ICW studies in various World Bank published reports and on its website.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fighting Corruption in Decentralized Indonesia 2007|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTJUSFORPOOR/Resources/FightingCorruptioninDecentralizedIndonesia.pdf|website=WorldBank.org|publisher=World Bank|accessdate=9 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Combating Corruption in Indonesia |url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTINDONESIA/Resources/Publication/03-Publication/Combating+Corruption+in+Indonesia-Oct15.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050121162752/http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTINDONESIA/Resources/Publication/03-Publication/Combating+Corruption+in+Indonesia-Oct15.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 January 2005 |website=WorldBank.org |publisher=World Bank |accessdate=9 August 2015 }}</ref> ICW's work and reports have also been cited in hundreds of academic works, books and journals about governmental and societal corruption.
Other recent indications of ICW's notability and influence include a request by the Jakarta Governor Basuki "Ahok" Tjahaja Prnama that ICW monitor the performance of government units under his administration,<ref>{{cite news|title=Ahok setting up anti corruption system|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/11/02/ahok-setting-anti-corruption-system.html|accessdate=9 August 2015|issue=2 November 2013|publisher=Jakarta Post|date=2 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ahok Requests ICW to Monitor Jakarta Officials|url=http://en.tempo.co/read/news/2014/08/12/057598977/Ahok-Requests-ICW-to-Monitor-Jakarta-Officials|accessdate=9 August 2015|publisher=Tempo International Media TBK|date=12 August 2014}}</ref> and arrests and reported harassment of ICW staff and activists by Indonesian police officers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Graft activists face questioning over libel|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/07/27/graft-activists-face-questioning-over-libel.html|accessdate=9 August 2015|publisher=The Jakarta Post|date=27 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Police told to stop harassment of activists|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/07/28/police-told-stop-harassment-activists.html|accessdate=9 August 2015|publisher=Jakarta Post|date=28 July 2015}}</ref> On September 2, 2015, Indonesian President Joko Widodo appointed former Indonesia Corruption Watch head [[Teten Masduki]] as his new chief of staff.<ref>{{cite news|title=Activist in the Hot Seat|url=http://en.tempo.co/read/news/2015/09/09/080698916/Activist-in-the-Hot-Seat|accessdate=15 September 2015|agency=Tempo|publisher=Tempo.co|date=9 September 2015}}</ref>
== Indonesian Culture of Corruption == :{{main|Corruption in Indonesia}} Indonesia has a serious problem with widespread corruption, which has been described as 'rampant' and impacting people from birth until death.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gunawan|first1=T. Sima|title=Why it's so difficult to eradicate corruption in Indonesia|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2006/05/24/why-it039s-so-difficult-eradicate-corruption-indonesia.html|accessdate=16 August 2015|publisher=The Jakarta Post|date=24 May 2006}}</ref> A 2014 study and report by [[Transparency International]] (TI) as reported in the [[Wall Street Journal]], disclosed that 72% of young Indonesians would engage in corruption for personal gain.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rachman|first1=Anita|title=In Indonesia, Acceptance of Corruption Starts Young|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indonesiarealtime/2014/05/29/in-indonesia-acceptance-of-corruption-starts-young/|accessdate=10 August 2015|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=29 May 2014}}</ref> In 2014, Indonesia placed 107 out of 175 countries on TI's [[Corruption Perceptions Index]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Corruption by Country, Indonesia|url=http://www.transparency.org/country/#IDN|website=Transparency International|publisher=Transparency International|accessdate=10 August 2015}}</ref> A 2003 World Bank study found that between 56 and 70% of all civil service employees were seen by their colleagues to be on the take.<ref>{{cite web|title=Combating Corruption in Indonesia |url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTINDONESIA/Resources/Publication/03-Publication/Combating+Corruption+in+Indonesia-Oct15.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050121162752/http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTINDONESIA/Resources/Publication/03-Publication/Combating+Corruption+in+Indonesia-Oct15.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 January 2005 |website=WorldBank.org |publisher=World Bank |accessdate=10 August 2015 }}</ref> While some attribute the current situation to a foundation of corruption laid during the reign of Indonesian strongman President Suharto, others blame a persisting 'culture of corruption' in Indonesia and the region that predates World War II.
== History and Role ==
ICW was created on June 21, 1998, a few weeks after the resignation of President [[Suharto]], by social activist [[Teten Masduki]], lawyer [[Todung Mulya Lubis]], economist [[Faisal Basri]] and other persons in the midst of a reform movement aimed at ensuring that any post-Suharto government would be democratic and free of corruption.
After the fall of Suharto it soon became apparent that the subsequent introduction of a decentralized mode of government with increased regional autonomy produced more corruption, and made its detection and control more difficult. Corruption in Indonesia was no longer organized and centralized, but became fragmented as new regional power centres and leaders emerged.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fighting Corruption in Decentralized Indonesia 2007|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTJUSFORPOOR/Resources/FightingCorruptioninDecentralizedIndonesia.pdf|website=WorldBank.org|publisher=World Bank|accessdate=10 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About ICW|url=https://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&hl=en&prev=search&rurl=translate.google.com&sl=id&u=http://antikorupsi.info/id/icw&usg=ALkJrhjtIiJ6o4VFG-qWIDslEREiRtrROw|website=Indonesia Corruption Watch, Google translated to English|publisher=Indonesia Corruption Watch|accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref> In this emerging situation ICW focused on bringing cases of corruption to the public and law enforcement agencies, monitoring campaign and political finance spending in national and local elections and pushing for anti-corruption laws such as the [[Freedom of Information Act]], the [[Whistleblower Protection Act]], Anti-corruption Act and Election Act.<ref>{{cite web|title=Indonesia Corruption Watch: Allard Prize Finalist|url=http://www.allardprize.org/indonesia-corruption-watch-allard-prize-finalist|website=Allard Prize for International Integrity|publisher=Peter A. Allard School of Law|accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref>
== Organization ==
ICW has 8 divisions, including:<ref>{{cite web|title=About ICW|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?depth=1&hl=en&prev=search&rurl=translate.google.com&sl=id&u=http://www.antikorupsi.org/id/ICW|website=Indonesia Corruption Watch|publisher=Indonesia Corruption Watch|accessdate=24 April 2017}}</ref>
* Law and Judicial Monitoring * Budget Monitoring and Analysis * Political Corruption * Research * Investigation * Networking * Public Campaign * Public Fundraising
== Recognition ==
On August 6, 2015, Indonesia Corruption Watch was nominated as one of four finalists for the CDN$100,000 [[University of British Columbia Faculty of Law#Allard Prize for International Integrity|Allard Prize for International Integrity]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Indonesia Corruption Watch: Allard Prize Finalist|url=http://www.allardprize.org/indonesia-corruption-watch-allard-prize-finalist|website=Allard Prize for International Integrity|publisher=Peter A. Allard School of Law|accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref> The other finalists include [[John Githongo]], [[Sergei Magnitsky]] and [[Rafael Marques de Morais]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Journalists, activists and advocacy group named finalists for Allard Prize for International Integrity|url=http://www.allardprize.org/news/journalists-activists-and-advocacy-group-named-finalists-allard-prize-international-integrity|website=Allard Prize for International Integrity|publisher=Peter A. Allard School of Law|accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref>
== Common News Media Naming Error ==
ICW's actual name in English is 'Indonesia Corruption Watch', as displayed in the organization's website and ICW's published reports.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official ICW website homepage|url=http://antikorupsi.info|website=Indonesia Corruption Watch|publisher=Indonesia Corruption Watch|accessdate=9 August 2015}}</ref> Archive searches of many major news organizations show that ICW's name is often reported in error as 'Indonesian Corruption Watch'. This inconsistent use of two names (one of them wrong) by the news media presents challenges to journalists and others researching ICW because two separate searches of each database are required to retrieve all news stories and available information. For instance, as of August 9, 2015 separate searches of the New York Times online archives are necessary to return 11 news stories under 'Indonesia Corruption Watch'<ref>{{cite news|title=New York Times archive search Indonesia Corruption Watch|url=https://query.nytimes.com/search/sitesearch/?action=click&contentCollection&region=TopBar&WT.nav=searchWidget&module=SearchSubmit&pgtype=Homepage#/"indonesia%20corruption%20watch"|accessdate=9 August 2015|publisher=New York Times}}</ref> and an additional 8 news stories under 'Indonesian Corruption Watch',<ref>{{cite news|title=New York Times - archive search 'Indonesian Corruption Watch'|url=https://query.nytimes.com/search/sitesearch/?action=click&contentCollection&region=TopBar&WT.nav=searchWidget&module=SearchSubmit&pgtype=Homepage#/%22indonesian+corruption+watch%22/|accessdate=9 August 2015|publisher=New York Times}}</ref> with Indonesia Corruption Watch (ICW) the intended subject of each news story reference. Other major news organizations' archives exhibit the same error in various proportions.
This frequently occurring naming error is also evident in government and academic publications. For instance, in the World Bank 2003 report Combating Corruption in Indonesia, both the correct and incorrect versions of ICW's official name are published in the same document.<ref>{{cite web|title=Combating Corruption In Indonesia |url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTINDONESIA/Resources/Publication/03-Publication/Combating+Corruption+in+Indonesia-Oct15.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050121162752/http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTINDONESIA/Resources/Publication/03-Publication/Combating+Corruption+in+Indonesia-Oct15.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 January 2005 |website=World Bank |publisher=World Bank |accessdate=9 August 2015 }}</ref>

'''Incorporated:''' 1967 |extinction = |type = |status = [[Private limited company]] (Ltd) |purpose = Dance education and examination board |headquarters = International House
76 Bennett Road
Brighton
BN2 5JL
United Kingdom |location = |region_served = UK and Worldwide |membership = |language = |leader_title = Chief Exec. |leader_name = Elizabeth Murphy |main_organ = Board of Directors |parent_organization = |affiliations = • British Dance Council
• Council for Dance Education & Training
• Central Council for Physical Recreation
• Theatre Dance Council International |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.idta.co.uk www.idta.co.uk] |remarks = }} The '''International Dance Teachers Association''' ('''IDTA''') is a leading dance teaching and examination board based in [[Brighton]], [[England]]. Operating internationally, the IDTA is one of the largest dance teaching organisations in the world and currently has over 7,000 members in 55 countries. The IDTA is a recognised awarding organisation, recognised by the national qualifications regulators in England and Wales, [[Ofqual]] and the [[Council for Dance Education and Training]], and is also affiliated to the [[British Dance Council]], the [[Central Council of Physical Recreation]] and the Theatre Dance Council International. The IDTA also works in partnership with the [[Royal Academy of Dance]]. It publishes their magazine for members Dance International four times a year. ==History== The International Dance Teachers Association was formed in 1967 as the result of a merger between the ''Dance Teachers' Association'' (DTA), and the ''International Dancing Masters Association'' (IDMA). Both these organisations were themselves formed from the merging of older dance teaching associations, with the earliest being established in 1903. The IDTA subsequently celebrated its centenary in 2003.Wainwright, Lyndon 1997. ''The story of British popular dance''. International Publications (IDTA), Brighton. The earliest predecessor of today's IDTA was the ''Manchester and Salford Association of Teachers of Dancing'', founded in 1903. This later became known as the ''Empire Society'', (ESTD), in 1938. In 1920, another group of teachers in Birmingham formed the ''Midland Association of Teachers of Dancing'' (MATD), which eventually merged with the Empire Society in 1961 to form the ''Dance Teachers' Association''. In the early post-[[World War I]] years, a number of other small dance organisations were formed: the ''English Dancing Masters Association'' (EDMA), the ''Premier Association of Teachers of Dancing'' (PATD), the ''Universal Association of Dane Teachers'' (UADT), and the ''Yorkshire Association of Dancing Masters'' (YADM). These four organisations merged in 1930 to form the ''International Dancing Masters' Association''. The final merger of these organisations in 1967, saw the creation of today's ''International Dance Teachers' Association''.Wainwright, p32. ==Activities== The IDTA exists primarily as a dance training and examination board. For students, the IDTA provides training opportunities with qualified dance teachers worldwide, both in private and mainstream dance education. Training is available in a wide range of dance disciplines, with examinations leading to a range of awards and certificates for successful candidates, including vocational examinations for students who wish to pursue a career in professional dance. Examinations and awards are available for a variety of ages and abilities. The IDTA also awards dance teaching qualifications and has a certification programme for dance students and professionals who wish to gain a recognised dance teaching qualification. There are three levels of qualification that certify teachers to enter candidates for IDTA examinations, they are ''Associate'', ''Licentiate'' and ''Fellowship''. Fellowship is the highest level of qualification within the IDTA and teachers who have reached this level may apply to become examiners of the IDTA. Beyond dance training and examinations, the IDTA is also one of the World's foremost organisations in the field of competitive dancing, and in this role organises numerous competitions, dance festivals and championships both in the UK and internationally, and is influential in the regulation and adjudication of such competitions. In the UK in particular, the IDTA organises the competitions for the much sought after titles of ''[[Miss Dance of Great Britain]]'' and ''[[Dance Master UK]]'', and also the ''IDTA Theatre Dance Championships''. Entrants for these prestigious competitions compete in heats at dance festivals nationwide throughout the year, for a place in the annual National finals in Blackpool. IDTA issues the quarterly ''Dance International Magazine'', which is distributed free of charge to all fully paid-up members of the organisation and includes important news for the period ahead. This includes information about any changes to the IDTA examination system, dates of meetings and seminars, general dance news and other vital information that teachers need. ==Dance styles== The IDTA is divided into two distinct branches, the [[Theatre Dance|Theatre Branch]] and the [[Ballroom Dance|Ballroom Branch]]. Each of these two sectors covers a range of dance styles, each with an elected faculty committee that oversee the standards and development of the discipline. The IDTA offers the following dance subjects: ===Theatre faculties=== * [[Classical Ballet]] * [[Freestyle dance|Freestyle]] * [[Acro dance|Gymnastic Dance]] * [[Modern Jazz]] * [[Musical Theatre]] * [[Rhythmic Gymnastics]] * [[Tap dance|Tap]] * [[Stage dance|Theatrecraft]] ===Ballroom faculties=== * [[Ballroom]] - Foxtrot, Quickstep, Slow Waltz, Tango, Viennese Waltz * Freestyle * [[Latin]] - Argentine Tango, Bachata, Cha Cha Cha, Jive, Mambo, Merengue, Paso Doble, Rumba, Salsa, Samba * [[Sequence dance]] - Saunter, Two Step, [[tango (ballroom)|Tango]], [[Swing (dance)]], [[Gavotte]], [[old time]] waltz, [[blues]] ==Teaching qualifications== ===Theatre branch=== People who wish to become dance teachers with the theatre branch of the IDTA can undertake a teacher training programme with an authorised member of the organisation. Candidates can undertake teacher training in one of the core theatre dance subjects of Ballet, Tap, Modern Jazz or Theatrecraft. To become recognised as a qualified teacher member of the IDTA, the candidate must achieve '''Associate''' status in at least one of these core subjects, which subsequently authorises them to teach the complete IDTA syllabus in all theatre dance subjects. There are five levels of certification for candidates undertaking teacher training: *'''Pre-Associate 1''': Denotes a student teacher who is not permitted to teach without supervision. Has studied part of the graded syllabus for the relevant subject *'''Pre-Associate 2''': Denotes a student teacher who is not permitted to teach without supervision. Has completed study of the graded syllabus for the relevant subject The following three levels are different levels of qualified teachers and all are authorised to teach the IDTA syllabus and enter candidates for examinations: *'''Associate (AIDTA)''': A qualified teacher who has completed detailed study in the teaching of the Intermediate syllabus for the relevant subject *'''Licentiate (LIDTA)''': A qualified teacher who has completed detailed study in the teaching of the Advanced 1 syllabus for the relevant subject *'''Fellowship (FIDTA)''': A qualified teacher who has completed detailed study in the teaching of the Advanced 2 syllabus for the relevant subject A teacher who has achieved Fellowship status in all four core subjects of the theatre branch, can apply to become an examiner for the branch. Candidates who are successful in the selection process to become an examiner, then visit dance schools as a representative of the organisation, assessing pupils' dancing and providing feedback on how they can improve. They also provide feedback to the teachers, to ensure that standards are being maintained and that the syllabus is being correctly taught. Examiners can also vote for and be nominated for election to one of the theatre branch's technical committees, which oversee the development of the syllabus in each discipline. This is one of the most senior roles in the organisation. ==Associations== From 1 October 2006, the IDTA began a new association with the London-based [[Royal Academy of Dance]]. A press release issued to members of each organisation stated that "the two organisations would embark on a process of working together for the future of dance and to the mutual benefit of their members in both teacher education and training and examinations". As a result of this association, registered teachers of the IDTA theatre dance branch are admitted as teacher members of the RAD and vice versa, teachers of the RAD are admitted to membership of the theatre branch of the IDTA. Whilst the new association is not a merger, it is intended that it will develop co-operation between the two organisations and mutual recognition of the training and qualifications that they both provide. It is also expected that in the future, both the IDTA and RAD will begin to work together, providing new training and development opportunities for members and students of both organisations. ==Structure== *President Phil Winston (this position is elected each year by the membership) *Chief Executive: Elizabeth Murphy *Finance Director: George Coad *Directors: elected each year ===Patrons=== *HRH Shaikha Mai Al Khalifa of Bahrain *[[Ronnie Fearn, Baron Fearn|Lord and Lady Fearn of Southport]] *[[Lionel Blair]] *Dame [[Yve Buckland]] *[[Donnie Burns]], [[Member of the Order of the British Empire|MBE]] *[[Dame Darcey Bussell]], [[Dame of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire|DBE]] * [[Dame Beryl Grey]] CH DBE *[[Karen and Marcus Hilton|Karen Hilton, MBE & Marcus Hilton, MBE]] *[[Stanley Ho]], [[Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire|OBE]] * [[Arlene Philips]] CBE * [[Dougie Squires]] OBE, MVO, * [[Ann Widdecombe]] ==Notable people== ===Ballroom branch=== * Guy Howard – Former dancer and teacher of Ballroom Dance and author of "Technique of Ballroom Dancing" * [[Walter Laird]] – Former dancer and teacher of Latin American Dance and author of "Technique of Latin American Dancing" * [[Len Goodman]] – Former Ballroom Dance Champion, now a teacher, examiner and adjudicator. Goodman was head judge on the BBC1 series [[Strictly Come Dancing]] from its inception in 2004 until he retired from the position in 2016. He also judged on the American equivalent series [[Dancing With The Stars]]. * [[Bassam Hanafi]] – The only Canadian Professional Examiner appointed by IDTA board. ===Theatre branch=== *'''[[Deborah Bull]]''' – Former Principal dancer with [[The Royal Ballet]]. Studied IDTA prior to joining the [[Royal Ballet School]] *'''Frances Clayton''' – Senior examiner and director of the IDTA. Founder and Principal of the ''Midlands Academy of Dance & Drama'', one of the UKs leading performing arts colleges *'''[[Vanessa Hooper]]''' – Former dancer with the [[Royal Ballet]] and [[Northern Ballet Theatre]]. Senior [[Academic examiner|examiner]] of the IDTA and dance tutor for the television series ''[[Ladette to Lady]]'' *'''[[Jennifer Ellison]]''' – British actress and model, who won titles at the IDTA Theatre Dance Championships in 1996 and 1997, later training at the [[Royal Ballet School|Royal Ballet Lower School]] *'''[[Kevin O'Hare]]''' – Studied IDTA and at the [[Royal Ballet School]]. Danced with [[Birmingham Royal Ballet]] and [[The Royal Ballet]] and is now Director of The Royal Ballet *'''[[Michael O'Hare (dancer)|Michael O'Hare]]''' – Studied IDTA and at the [[Royal Ballet School]]. Danced with [[Birmingham Royal Ballet]] and [[The Royal Ballet]] and is now [[Ballet Master]] for Birmingham Royal Ballet *'''[[Natasha Oughtred]]''' – Studied IDTA and at the [[Royal Ballet School]]. Former dancer with the Royal Ballet, currently a Principal dancer with the Birmingham Royal Ballet *'''[[Gavin Roebuck]]''' former ballet dancer and presenter writes in the IDTA magazine. *'''Patricia Lupino-Thompson''' – Senior examiner and theatre council member of the IDTA. Is most noted for being a living descendent of the famous [[Lupino family]] ===Honorary members=== * [[Arlene Phillips]] was admitted as an honorary member of the IDTA in 2006, in recognition of her work in the field of dance. Phillips is credited with the creation of 70s dance troup [[Hot Gossip]], and is the renowned choreographer of award-winning [[West End theatre|West End]] and [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] musicals including [[Sound of Music#2006 London revival|The Sound Of Music]], [[Starlight Express]], [[Grease (musical)|Grease]], [[Saturday Night Fever (musical)|Saturday Night Fever]] and [[We Will Rock You (musical)|We Will Rock You]]. She is most famous today as a judge for television talent shows, such as [[Strictly Come Dancing]] and [[So You Think You Can Dance (UK)|So You Think You Can Dance]]. * [[Sir Ken Dodd]] was admitted as an honorary member of the IDTA in recognition of his contribution to the entertainments industry. Dodd who died in 2018 was a well-known British comedian, most famous for traditional music hall style entertainment, although he also appeared in drama and is a songwriter. * [[Rosemarie Ford]] is a well-known British television personality from the 1990s, particularly recognised as [[Bruce Forsyth|Bruce Forsyth's]] co-presenter of [[The Generation Game]]. Rosemarie Poundford, to give her full name, trained as a dancer with an IDTA teacher from a young age and in 1978, won the prestigious title of "Miss Dance of Great Britain". In 1998, she performed the role of [[Bombalurina (cat)|'Bombalurina']] for the official film production of [[Andrew Lloyd Webber|Andrew Lloyd Webber's]] musical [[Cats (musical)|"Cats".]] ==See also== {{Portal|Dance}} *[[UKA Dance]] *[[British Association of Teachers of Dance]] (BATD) *[[British Ballet Organization]] (BBO) *[[Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing]] (ISTD) *[[National Association of Teachers of Dancing]] (NATD) *[[Royal Academy of Dance]] (RAD) ==References== {{Reflist}} *''Dance International Magazine'', March–April 2008 ==External links== *[http://www.idta.co.uk IDTA Official Website] *[http://www.freewebs.com/missdanceofgreatbritain/ Miss Dance of Great Britain]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[Category:Dance education organizations]] [[Category:Dance in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Performing arts education in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Professional associations based in the United Kingdom|Dance Teachers]] [[Category:Organisations based in Brighton and Hove]]

{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=February 2015}} {{original research|date=February 2015}} {{COI|date=February 2015}} }} '''Jim Calarco''' is an actor and a media and drama instructor.
== Early life == Calarco's hometown is [[North Bay, Ontario]].
==Career== ===Teaching and stage=== He taught media and drama classes from 1969 to 2000.<ref name="cottagecountrynow">{{cite web|url=http://www.cottagecountrynow.ca/whatson-story/3571000-writer-s-wish-comes-true-with-new-film/ |title=Writer's wish comes true with new film |publisher=Cottagecountrynow.ca |date=2011-11-24 |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> His career began when he was working as the Artistic Director of Caruso's Dinner Theatre in North Bay in 1981 and 1982. Claire and Jim Calarco formed Pine Creek Theatre Productions in 1983, producing independent freelance theatre. Calarco was a drama consultant with the Near North School Board of Education prior to retirement in 2000.
After retiring from teaching, Calarco focused his career exclusively on film and television.
=== Film and television === Calarco became a board member of Loon Film Productions and of [[Nipissing University]]'s Nipissing Stage in 2007. He served as a member of the Theatrical Advisory Committee for [[Canadore College]] between 2008 and 2009. Calarco worked through various casting agencies to seek new talent within northern Ontario by promoting original, innovative film development as a spokesperson for the Show Us Your Shorts film competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sootoday.com/content/arts/details.asp?c=21541 |title=Show us your shorts |website= Sootoday.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> In 2008, he formed Real to Reel BG Agency with Kate Adams.
Calarco is a member of [[ACTRA]] and the [[Actors' Equity Association]]. His most recent works include ''[[A Dark Truth]]'', ''The Riverbank'' (also known as ''Tracing Iris'') and ''One Wish''. ''One Wish'' won the [[Mexico City International Film Festival]]'s Golden Palm Award and the [[Canada International Film Festival]]'s Award of Excellence.<ref name="northbaynipissing">{{cite web| url= http://www.northbaynipissing.com/2012/03/one-wish-receives-acclaim-at-west-coast-film-festiva/ |title=One Wish receives acclaim at west coast film festival |publisher=Northbaynipissing.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref>
In 2010, Calarco established North Star Talent Agency<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sootoday.com/content/arts/details.asp?c=29797 |title=New talent agency represents northern actors |publisher=Sootoday.com |date=2010-01-08 |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> with producer [[Brigitte Kingsley]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baytoday.ca/content/news/details.asp?c=34963 |title=City sees first talent agency open |publisher=Baytoday.ca |date=2010-01-06 |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> to better represent actors from northern Ontario. Within the same year he started Real to Reel BG Agency with Kate Adams. In 2011, Calarco started Castnorth,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.castnorth.ca/about-us |title=About Us — CAST North |website= Castnorth.ca |date= |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> a film and television casting and audition agency.
Many of Calarco's latest movies have been available on [[Super Channel (Canada)|Super Channel]], including ''[[Dark Rising]]'' 1 and 2, ''[[A Dark Truth]]'', ''High Chicago'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nugget.ca/2011/08/07/zombies-demons-target-city|title=Zombies, demons target city|work=North Bay Nugget}}</ref> ''The Riverbank'' and ''The Entitled''.
''[[North Bay Nugget]]'' was released in September 2013: "Calarco can now add the Northern Flicks Award — ''top honours'' in [[CTV Television Network]] Best in Shorts competition — to his list of awards from a film that put the spotlight on [[dementia]] and [[Alzheimer's]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nugget.ca/2013/09/25/film-strangers-earns-honour|title=Strangers earns honour|work=North Bay Nugget}}</ref>
==Awards== Calarco won the Quonta Best Actor award in 1973<ref name="media.cottagecountrynow">{{cite web|url=http://media.cottagecountrynow.ca/special/almaguin/data/pdfs/95/AN12.pdf |format=PDF|title=Almaguin data|publisher=Media.cottagecountrynpow.ca|accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> and in 2008 was inducted into the Northern Ontario Entertainers Hall of Fame.<ref name="nugget">{{cite web|author=nurun.com |url=http://www.nugget.ca/2009/01/12/hall-president-humbled-by-honour |title=Hall president humbled by honour |publisher=North Bay Nugget |date=2009-01-12 |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> Many of Calarco’s recent shorts have been nominated for awards, some as finalists, and his movies won many festival awards. *1973 How The Other Half Lives – Best Actor Quonta Festival - Frank *2007 That Was Easy – Best Screenplay<ref name="media.cottagecountrynow" /> from Music and Film in Motion Awards, Nomination<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baytoday.ca/content/arts/details.asp?c=25491 |title=Adams and Calarco go head to head |publisher=Baytoday.ca |date=2008-04-29 |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> and [https://web.archive.org/web/20110922075308/http://www.baytoday.ca/content/arts/details.asp?c=27870 finalist] from Music in Film and Motion Festival *2008 Inducted into the Northern Ontario Entertainers Hall of Fame<ref name="nugget" /> *2011 The House - CTV Best In Shorts:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.cottagecountrynow.ca/special/almaguin/data/pdfs/95/AN12.pdf |title=Finalist |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> Film North: Finalist, [[Mexico City International Film Festival]]:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nugget.ca/2011/05/25/award-validation-for-filmmaker|title=Award 'validation' for filmmaker|work=North Bay Nugget}}</ref> Silver Palm Award,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northernstars.ca/actorsabc/calarco_jim.html |title=Jim Calarco |website= Northernstars.ca |date= |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> ICFILMS (Milan): Top Twenty finalist *2012 One Wish<ref name="cottagecountrynow" /> — [[Mexico City International Film Festival]]: Golden Palm Award, [[Canada International Film Festival]]: Award of Excellence<ref name="northbaynipissing" /> *2013 Strangers – Mexico City International Film Festival: Bronze Palm Award,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baytoday.ca/content/news/details.asp?c=52403 |title=Strangers captures bronze at Mexico International Film Festival |publisher=Baytoday.ca |date=2013-06-11 |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> Canada International Film Festival: Award of Excellence, [[Cinéfest Sudbury International Film Festival]] Northern Flicks Award and winner at The Rimini Italy Film Festival
==Personal life== Calarco and his wife Claire married in 1969.
==Filmography== Calarco has performed as an actor, producer, writer, director, casting director, musician and voiceover artist.

[[File:Knut almlöf som harpagon nornan 1894 s 74.jpg|thumb|right|Knut Almlöf]] '''Knut Almlöf''' (9 February 1829 [[Stockholm]] – 3 January 1899, Almnäs, Gripsholm), was a Swedish stage actor. He was an elite actors of the [[Royal Dramatic Theatre]] and belonged to the most famed stage actors of his time in Sweden.
==Life== Knut Almlöf was the son of the actors [[Nils Almlöf]] and Brita Catharina Cederberg.
He had an early enthusiasm to become an actor. His father, one of his country's most famous actors, did not want him to become an actor, and sent him to be educated to a priest in Uppsala. His mother died when he was nine, and the year after, his father remarried the celebrated [[Charlotta Almlöf|Charlotta Ficker]] of the [[Royal Dramatic Theatre]]. She encouraged Knut in his interest for the theatre, and after his graduation in 1848, they convinced his father about his preference.
In 1851, he joined the troupe of [[Pierre Deland]], where he married his colleague [[Betty Deland]]. He was employed at the theatre ''[[Mindre teatern]]'' in Stockholm in 1861, and in the Royal Dramatic Theatre in 1863.
He was regarded to have a natural way of acting and was referred to as a genius in comedy.
In 1874–77, he was joint principal of ''[[Dramatens elevskola]]'' with his wife. He took the death of his wife 1882 very hard and retired from the theatre, but continued to act as a guest artist until 1897.
== References== * [http://www.dramaten.se/default.asp?id=3900 Kungliga Dramatiska teatern] * [http://runeberg.org/sbh/almlknut.html Svenskt biografiskt handlexikon]
